oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Making Window Screens
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: African Americans; Windows; Construction; Screens
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: A group of students are making window screens. The completed screens would probably have been used to keep out mosquitos.
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Mustard, Harry S. (Harry Stoll), 1889-1966
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Dr. Harry Mustard worked in Rutherford County, Tennessee, durning the 1930's on behalf of the Rockefeller Foundation's Commonwealth Fund. He took photographs as part of a five-year study of health and sanitation conditions of rural children. Dr. Mustard; went on to become a very prominent public health administrator.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Home hygiene class making layette
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Women; Home economics; Sewing; Layettes; Sewing equipment & supplies
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Eight unidentified women in a classroom making layettes. A singer sewing machine stand is pictured. A layette is a collection of clothing and bedding items for a newborn child.
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Mustard, Harry S. (Harry Stoll), 1889-1966
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Dr. Harry Mustard worked in Rutherford County, Tennessee, during the 1920's on behalf of the Rockefeller Foundation's Commonwealth Fund. oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Cleaning teeth during class period
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Dental hygiene; Health education; Children; School children; Teachers; Classrooms
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: A dental hygienist cleans the teeth of a young boy during a class period. The other students are seated at their desks and are doing their work.
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Mustard, Harry S. (Harry Stoll), 1889-1966
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Dr. Harry Mustard worked in Rutherford County, Tennessee, during the 1920's on behalf of the Rockefeller Foundation's Commonwealth Fund. He took photographs as part of a five-year study of health and sanitation conditions of rural children. Dr. Mustard; went on to become a very prominent public health administrator. Even though Mustard's efforts were often met with resistance and skepticism, children were encouraged to form better health habits, such as brushing their teeth twice daily.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Oil spraying for mosquito control
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Pest control; Equipment; Health
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: An African-American man uses an oil sprayer to aid in mosquito control. He wears the equipment on his back, which includes a large metal can and a spraying device.
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Mustard, Harry S. (Harry Stoll), 1889-1966
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Dr. Harry Mustard worked in Rutherford County, Tennessee, during the 1920's on behalf of the Rockefeller Foundation's Commonwealth Fund. He took photographs as part of a five-year study of health and sanitation conditions of rural children. Dr. Mustard; went on to become a very prominent public health administrator.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Nurse explaining maternity exhibit and prenatal exhibit
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Nurses; Prenatal care; Medical education
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Using an educational exhibit, a nurse explains to a woman the basics of prenatal care. The exhibit includes examples of baby clothing, supplies, a basket, a crib, and bedding.
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Mustard, Harry S. (Harry Stoll), 1889-1966
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Dr. Harry Mustard worked in Rutherford County, Tennessee, during the 1920's on behalf of the Rockefeller Foundation's Commonwealth Fund. He took photographs as part of a five-year study of health and sanitation conditions of rural children. Dr. Mustard; went on to become a very prominent public health administrator.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Health lesson in fourth grade
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Nutrition; Education; Health; Food; Children; School children; Classrooms; Teachers
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: A young girl learns the basics of a healthy breakfast with the help of a teacher. The blackboard reads, "Menu for breakfast, Oatmeal and cream, Egg on toast, Milk, Baked apple." The young girl is wearing a dress but no shoes.
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Mustard, Harry S. (Harry Stoll), 1889-1966
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Dr. Harry Mustard worked in Rutherford County, Tennessee, during the 1920's on behalf of the Rockefeller Foundation's Commonwealth Fund. He took photographs as part of a five-year study of health and sanitation conditions of rural children. Dr. Mustard; went on to become a very prominent public health administrator. Mustard and his staff determined that successful public health initiatives began at the grassroots level and usually involved women and children.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Spread at Lavergne and Blue Ribbon Contest
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Picnics; Contests
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: A group of men, women, and children gather together for a contest or celebration of some sort.
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Mustard, Harry S. (Harry Stoll), 1889-1966
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Dr. Harry Mustard worked in Rutherford County, Tennessee, during the 1920's on behalf of the Rockefeller Foundation's Commonwealth Fund. He took photographs as part of a five-year study of health and sanitation conditions of rural children. Dr. Mustard; went on to become a very prominent public health administrator. Blue ribbon health contests provided local citizens with an opportunity and competitive incentive to practice their school health lessons.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Lesson in Sanitation at Country Store
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Country life; Sanitation; Hygiene; General stores; Men; Signs (Notices); Horses
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Shows a group of men on the front porch of a country store with a sign hanging in the doorway that says "Headquarters for School Supplies." One man is sitting on a horse at left.

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Dr. Harry Mustard worked in Rutherford County, Tennessee, during the 1920s on behalf of the Rockefeller Foundation's Commonwealth Fund. oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: School children; Students; Rural schools; Sanitation; Hygiene; Drinking fountains; Wells

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Health Center poster
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Posters; Health education; Health care; Vaccinations; School children; Hygiene; Preventive medicine; Children
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Poster entitled "Has Your Child Won a Decoration in the Army of Health?" used in a health center advocating vaccinations and general good health of children aged 2 to 6 years. A boy and girl standing in profile are pictured.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: May Day Float
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Hygiene; Health care; School children; May poles; Health education; Trucks; Houses; City and town life; Parades and processions; Floats; Streets

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Double House
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Houses; Thatched roof buildings; Chimneys; Country life; Outbuildings
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: View of a double clapboard siding, thatched-roof house with chimneys on each end which shows a sparsely planted yard with one lone tree devoid of leaves and one small outbuilding in the rear. A ladder can be seen on the roof.
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Mustard, Harry S. (Harry Stoll), 1889-1966
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Dr. Harry Mustard worked in Rutherford County, Tennessee, during the 1930s on behalf of the Rockefeller Foundation's Commonwealth Fund. He took photographs as part of a five-year study of health and sanitation conditions of rural children. Dr. Mustard; went on to become a very prominent public health administrator.
